title: Sunset Point, Pushkar by Muslianshah Masrie
text:
Sunset Point, Pushkar by Muslianshah Masrie
“I shot this on a visit to Pushkar, India. The location is appropriately called ‘Sunset Point’. We travelled here via motorcycle and camel to arrive in time for the spectacular sunset.”

title: Nature Boy by Alessio Albi
text:
Nature Boy by Alessio Albi
“That was a luck shot. I used the multiple exposure function of my camera, shooting the tree and then my father’s face. I adjusted the contrast slightly in post processing. I was very happy with the result.”

title: The Lucky Seal by Harry Egens
text:
The Lucky Seal by Harry Egens
“While one seal ended its live in the jaws of the Great White Shark, the Cape Fur Seal on the right was lucky. The shot was taken early morning just after sunrise in False Bay near Seal Island in South Africa.”

title: Down the Road by Alexey Gusev
text:
Down the Road by Alexey Gusev
“The girl on this photo is my daughter Barbara. This was taken during our vacation on Crete last year where we found a spectacular place; a cemetery of old cars. We used one of the cars for the portrait.”

title: Storm on the Sea by Yan Larsen
text:
Storm on the Sea by Yan Larsen
“This picture was taken in the Lofoten Islands, Norway. The weather was bad, and I sat in my car for three hours to take this shot, waiting for a break in the clouds. Outside, the wind was so strong I could hardly stand!”

title: Ghostly Cub by Jordi Fernandez
text:
Ghostly Cub by Jordi Fernandez
“I took this in Lebala camp, Botswana. We were photographing lionesses when this cub approached us from behind. I lay as low as possible on the car for a low angle while trying to get the sun disk out of the frame.”

title: Surge by Alex De Sonnaville
text:
Surge by Alex De Sonnaville
“This was taken at Natural Bridges State Park in Santa Cruz, California. I originally set out to take long exposures, but decided to go with a quicker shutter speed in order to take advantage of the great foreground created by the waves.”

title: Burning Peak by Shantikara T. Valuska
text:
Burning Peak by Shantikara T. Valuska
“The Matterhorn reflected in a small mountain lake high up in the Alps. I hiked up here very early in the morning to catch the magical moment when the first rays of the sun touch the top of the mountain.”

title: Freedom by Guillermina Sogo
text:
Freedom by Guillermina Sogo
“This was taken during the first day of ‘Rapas das Bestas’ in Sabucedo, Spain. About 200 wild horses are caught, then marked with microchips before being set free. Here the heat from the horses produced a steam visible in the shot.”

title: Issue 99 of Photography Week is on sale now!
text:
Issue 99 of Photography Week is on sale now!
This week’s we take the best quotes from some of the biggest names in photography and explore what you can take from them to improve your own photography – from Capa to Cartier-Bresson, this is a masterclass you won’t want to miss.

title: Horse Ballet by Lisa Mardell
text:
Horse Ballet by Lisa Mardell
“A Lusitano stallion showing off for the camera at the Coudelaria Henrique Abecasis stud farm in Portugal. Lusitanos love to perform and their big personalities and beautiful manes make them a compelling subject to photograph.”

title: Cantabria Infinita… by Jose Miquel Romano
text:
Cantabria Infinita… by Jose Miquel Romano
“This place is known as Los Urros, near Liencres in Cantabria, Spain. The photograph was taken late one day. The moon illuminated the scene from the left, while the setting sun provided the warm lighting from the right.”

title: Priceless Moments by Ash Kapoor
text:
Priceless Moments by Ash Kapoor
“I took this on a walk in Varanasi on the banks of the Ganga in India. I saw this old lady sitting outside her house, and felt a connection with her. I chatted with her, then asked if I could take her picture.”

title: A New Beginning by Ash Kapoor
text:
A New Beginning by Ash Kapoor
“I took this shot on an early morning walk on the Ghats of Varanasi, India, where I saw this pandit (priest) relaxing. The sun was just rising, and I found it interesting to get this low angle shot showing the horizon.”

title: Súla / Northern Gannet / Morus Bassanus by Ágúst Þór Bjarnason
text:
Súla / Northern Gannet / Morus Bassanus by Ágúst Þór Bjarnason
“The Northern Gannet is the largest member of the Gannet family. I was at sea south-west of the Faroe Islands when I took this photo, which is one of many that evening in perfect dawn and seascape environment.”

title: Nate Florence at Pipeline by John Hook
text:
Nate Florence at Pipeline by John Hook
This was a huge swell on the north shore of Oahu island, Hawaii. I swam out with my camera and stayed in position for a few hours shooting. As the sun set it made a beautiful backlight from the wave.“

title: Flapping Wings by Nando Pizzini
text:
Flapping Wings by Nando Pizzini
“I took this shot of an Atlantic puffin flapping its wings one evening on the Runde Cliffs, an island that lies off the western coast of Norway.”

title: Gold Bar Rim - Moab Canyon below - Moab, UT by Eddie Tkowski
text:
Gold Bar Rim - Moab Canyon below - Moab, UT by Eddie Tkowski
“I’ve known about this spot for some time, having mountain biked here for years. I tell people to go to the edge for the view, but they have no idea they’re on an overhang like this!”

title: Latest issue of Photography Week out now!
text:
Latest issue of Photography Week out now!
This week we have a fantastic creative photo project for you to try that involves a feather, some water droplets and a close-up lens. Oh, and if you haven’t got a dedicated macro lens, we show you how to get up close and personal on a budget.

title: Erm by Marc Jardot
text:
Erm by Marc Jardot
“I wanted to make a high contrast image. As the weather was favorable, we headed out to shoot, and I chose this place as the background would create a great bokeh and would be good for a high contrast image.”

title: Up, up and away by Vichaya Chatikavanij
text:
Up, up and away by Vichaya Chatikavanij
“I took this during a trip to West Java, Indonesia. To get this composition of children playing in the water, I also had to wade out to the middle of the stream. The blur is from the morning fog and backlighting.”

title: Nykvåg, Vesterålen by Gian Paolo Chiesi
text:
Nykvåg, Vesterålen by Gian Paolo Chiesi
“I took this in Vesterålen in northern Norway, on the rocks to the right of beautiful Nykvåg beach. I used a 3 stop soft Lee filter.”

title: Great Migration by Nicole Cambré
text:
Great Migration by Nicole Cambré
“Wildebeest crossing the Mara River in Northern Serengeti, a remote part of Tanzania. The crossing lasted for nearly an hour and a half, and we were very lucky to see it as this is not a place the animals usually cross.”

title: Yosemite Dreams by Heather West
text:
Yosemite Dreams by Heather West
“This was taken at Yosemite National Park in California, at Glacier Point. I wanted to capture the immensity and geologic diversity of Yosemite, and adding a human subject helped give scale and connects the viewer to the landscape.”

title: Markús frá Langholtsparti by Gígja Einarsdottir
text:
Markús frá Langholtsparti by Gígja Einarsdottir
“I love to photograph horses, and this time I was lucky to be asked to photograph this Icelandic horse for the cover of the Icelandic stallion magazine. He is very well known here in Iceland for producing good offspring.”

title: Irish Bee by Daniel Korzhonov
text:
Irish Bee by Daniel Korzhonov
“This is St Jones Point in Northern Ireland. It’s an amazing lighthouse, and not automated yet. From the other side of the lighthouse you’d be able to see the Mourne Mountains, which inspired Lewis Carroll to create the Narnia Chronicles.”

title: New issue of Photography Week out now!
text:
New issue of Photography Week out now!
This week we reveal the 13 image-editing mistakes we all make, and give you practical advice on how to avoid them. Plus, we chat to a lifestyle pro about documenting Britain’s most eccentric activities, have a close encounter with an underwater photographer, reveal how to banish shadows from sunlit portraits, and get our hands on Nikon’s latest full-framer - the D810. There’s plenty more besides…

title: On Cloud Nine by Robert Sommer
text:
On Cloud Nine by Robert Sommer
“On the small German island of Heligoland in the North Sea, there are a lot of Northern Gannets. You can get very close to them, providing some great photo opportunities!”

title: Whinchat by Brian Arbuthnot
text:
Whinchat by Brian Arbuthnot
“This shot of a rare migrant Whinchat was taken in Wicklow National Park, Ireland. This shy bird nests on the ground among ferns. Once in position I set my camera just above fern level, and eventually got this shot through a gap.”

title: Bandon by Nathan Wirth
text:
Bandon by Nathan Wirth
“It had been raining most of the day when I set up for this image at Face Rock Beach in Bandon, Oregon. The sun suddenly burst through the clouds, making it nearly impossible to capture anything, so I positioned myself so the sun was just behind the rock.”

title: Orangutan by Jose Manuel Garcia
text:
Orangutan by Jose Manuel Garcia
“This orangutan lives in Barcelona Zoo. It’s not easy to photograph animals in these conditions; people often get in the way, and merky windows separate us from the animals. It took several attempts until I finally captured this pose.”

title: Swimming Umbrellas by Fokion L. Zissiadis
text:
Swimming Umbrellas by Fokion L. Zissiadis
“On a morning walk, my interest was caught by the juxtaposition of the elevated infinity pool and the beach of the Sani Beach Resort in Greece. The umbrellas against the backdrop of the sea reflected in the water, forming an almost total symmetry.”

title: Water Vole by Nick Holland
text:
Water Vole by Nick Holland
“The photo was taken at a private site in Kent, near Maidstone, on an old mill pond. I was sat in the river in my chest waders to get low enough to capture the beautiful reflection!”

title: Red Balloon by Kira Hanson
text:
Red Balloon by Kira Hanson 
“This was taken on the Sunshine Coast, Queensland. The little boy was throwing the balloon up as high as he could, the silhouette and the sun lighting the balloon with such vibrancy struck me immediately, and I quickly snapped the shot.”

title: Ruby-throated hummingbird by Philip Sorrentino
text:
Ruby-throated hummingbird by Philip Sorrentino
“Ruby-throated hummingbirds frequent the nectar feeders in my in-laws’ backyard. I lit the scene with four flash units; one for the background, and the remaining three aimed at the flower and bird.”

title: De la distance focale de l'être sensible by Chris Dève
text:
De la distance focale de l'être sensible by Chris Dève
“Standing in a white field, the sun came out at the right moment. I placed a filter on my lens, lining it with vaseline and a touch of purple paint to create this soft bokeh effect.”

title: Excuse me please, you’re standing in my space by Mia S Borin
text:
Excuse me please, you’re standing in my space by Mia S Borin
“Earlier this year we didn’t have many butterflies around where I live in the middle of Sweden, but now they’re slowly beginning to appear. One morning I was fortunate to come across this confident little guy!”

title: Twisted times by Amy Haslehurst
text:
Twisted times by Amy Haslehurst
“This was taken toward the end of the day at a nature reserve close to my house. I decided to try and get a very shallow depth of field, with the brown tones of the grass contrasting with my skin.”

title: Storm by David Bellier
text:
Storm by David Bellier
“This was taken during a storm in Picardie, France during my hunt for four intense storm supercells. I used a wide lens to create the surreal atmosphere and power of this memorable evening.”

title: Burning Mountain by Florent Chevalier
text:
Burning Mountain by Florent Chevalier
“This is the 8,000-meter peak of Dhaulagiri at sunset seen from the Kali Gandaki, Nepal. It is the seventh highest summit in the world. I took this picture during a three-week trek around the Annapurnas.”

title: Love is in the air by Wojchiech Grzanka
text:
Love is in the air by Wojchiech Grzanka
“The courtship display of the Great Crested Grebe is fascinating to watch. I took this shot in Poland in between two thunderstorms! I suppose the birds didn’t expect they were being watched, and that’s how I got this very intimate picture.”

title: New issue of Photography Week out now!
text:
New issue of Photography Week out now!
This week we reveal the one thing that you can do – today – to transform your landscape images, literally overnight. We also discover what it’s like to shoot in pounding surf just metres away from molten lava; go head to head with a classic steam locomotive; and show you how to banish pesky pedestrians from your travel photos. All this plus our usual mix of inspirational galleries, news, reviews and videos!

title: Violinist by Irma Kaňová
text:
Violinist by Irma Kaňová
“This photo tells the story of a violinist who ran away from the concert hall. She found shelter on a roof, where she enjoyed peace and quiet, finally able to play her own way.”

title: Sea Gypsy Village by Duratul Ain Duhamid
text:
Sea Gypsy Village by Duratul Ain Duhamid
“This photo was taken at Semporna in Sabah, Malaysia, during a trip to explore this beautiful island. I was amazed to witness how the sea gypsies get through their daily lives.”

title: Toscana by Irca Caplikas
text:
Toscana by Irca Caplikas
“Toscana is a very beautiful place, but it isn’t easy to take good pictures because the right light is only found early in the morning. I was very happy with this shot as the mist provided a good light.”

title: Eigerøy lighthouse by Richard Larssen
text:
Eigerøy lighthouse by Richard Larssen 
“With my camera mounted on a tripod, I shot an exposure at 1.3 seconds to capture the light in the tower and to create the silky effect in the water. I edited the image in Adobe Lightroom.”

title: Stone and Mirror by Jessica Lia
text:
Stone and Mirror by Jessica Lia
“The idea behind this self portrait was about how we often build walls around us to protect ourselves, but eventually we become stuck inside. The darkness and pebbles convey the layers of fragments of ourselves.”

title: Me and the Mountain by Rodney Allen
text:
Me and the Mountain by Rodney Allen
“Mount Taranaki/Egmont (2518m) and tarn on the Pouakai Rangers, New Zealand. I spent a cold night beside the tarn waiting for completely still water. This happened just before sunrise, with the full moon about to set.”

title: Marie-Lou by Dimitry Roulland
text:
Marie-Lou by Dimitry Roulland
“I took this photo in Limoges, France with this young gymnast called Marie-Lou. As it was a rainy day, we decided to shoot under a bus shelter, and this is the result.”

title: New issue of Photography Week out now!
text:
New issue of Photography Week out now!
In this week’s feature we reveal the eight tripod mistakes every photographer makes, and how to avoid them. Plus, we meet up with a world-renowned wildlife pro to discover the key to ensuring your images stand out from the crowd; go behind the scenes of a death-defying high-dive shoot in the Azores; show you when and how to use manual focus; and walk you through the basics of dodging and burning to add punch to your pictures in Photoshop.

title: Sydney Opera House Red Sky by Martin Tyler
text:
Sydney Opera House Red Sky by Martin Tyler
“An early May morning in Sydney, Australia. The sky and the harbour water lit up red by the rising sun around the Sydney Opera House.”

title: Purple Gallinule Feeding by Judy Malloch
text:
Purple Gallinule Feeding by Judy Malloch
“This is a purple gallinule. I took the shot as I watched him feed on the fire flag plants.  Their favourite food seems to be the small lilac flowers at the end of the branch, which they sometimes struggle to reach.”

title: Morning at the Camp by Jon Harris
text:
Morning at the Camp by Jon Harris
“This spot in east Devon is well known for it’s amazing yearly display of bluebells. An early rise was needed to catch the first light on a beautiful spring morning. Not another soul in sight, just myself and the dawn chorus. Simply magical!”

title: El Acantilado Negro by Juan Antonio Santana
text:
El Acantilado Negro by Juan Antonio Santana
“This composite of three images was taken in Fuerteventura, Spain. I blended the two images of stars in Photoshop and lightened them, and for the foreground I adjusted the colour, saturation, brightnes and contrast using Nik Color Efex Pro.”

title: Broken Sundowns by Amy Haslehurst
text:
Broken Sundowns by Amy Haslehurst
“This picture was taken by the sea in Kalbarri, Western Australia. The water was very violent, so trying to take a self portrait with my camera balanced on a rock was difficult as the waves threatened to drench me!”

title: Falling by Haakon Nygård
text:
Falling by Haakon Nygård
“I took this in Sunndal, Norway, beside one of the many waterfalls coming down from tall mountains surrounding the valley. The image contains tree bracketed exposures, one for the sky, one for the valley and one for the waterfall.”

title: Foggy Sunrise by Marcos Güell
text:
Foggy Sunrise by Marcos Güell
“This was taken at dawn in Extremadura, Spain. The sky was clear and the lighting perfect for capturing a wonderful atmosphere. This stork nesting in the water is quite a rare sight as they mainly nest above roofs and trees.”

title: Issue 93 of Photography Week out now!
text:
Issue 93 of Photography Week out now!
In this week’s feature we show you how to take stand-out travel shots and still have a relaxing holiday with family and friends; from planning your day to ideas, advice and inspiration, our practical, real-world guide will tell you all you need to know.

title: Ana Aterhortua by Camilo Álvarez
text:
Ana Aterhortua by Camilo Álvarez
“This was taken as part of a photo shoot for the collection ‘Coffee Arabica’ by the Colombian clothing brand Moss. The model is Ana Atehortua, and the makeup artist was María Fernanda Velez.”

title: Mumbai, Gateway of India by Julie Mayfeng
text:
Mumbai, Gateway of India by Julie Mayfeng
“When I visited the Gateway of India, the air was clear and the sunlight was spreading from the Arabian Sea. The moment I took the shot, someone hit the metal guard rail with a crash, frightening the pigeons to take flight.”

title: Al-Marmoum Race by Shoayb Khattab
text:
Al-Marmoum Race by Shoayb Khattab
“This was taken at Al-Marmoum Camel Raching, a popular annual event in Dubai. I wanted to show the sense of action in the race, so put the camera on the ground, giving me a different angle than other shots.”

title: Horse’s Breakfast by Maxim Khytra
text:
Horse’s Breakfast by Maxim Khytra
“I took this photo near Lviv, Ukraine. One foggy morning I was searching for a nice view to take a photo of the sunrise. I heard horses neighing from through the fog, and found these two.”

title: Ombre Danzanti by Michele Tusi
text:
Ombre Danzanti by Michele Tusi
“This was taken at a contemporary dance show by group ‘Muvs’ in Casalmaggiore theatre in northern Italy. I took the shot using a tripod, then later edited the shot in Lightroom.”

title: Rural Landscape by Notley Hawkins
text:
Rural Landscape by Notley Hawkins
“I took this shot of a barn near Hartsburg in Boone County, Missouri. I chose a low-angle with a f2.8 aperture to blur the foreground, creating the sensation of the barn in a sea of purple.”

title: While the sky whirls away by Derek Finch
text:
While the sky whirls away by Derek Finch
“This is a 26 minute composite exposure of the night sky over Halnaker windmill near Chichester, West Sussex. I captured this just after I had taken a similar photo of a Space Station transit.”

title: New issue out now!
text:
New issue out now!
In this week’s issue we’ve got two quick and easy photo projects for you to try, neither of which involve venturing any further than your back garden: in the first we show you how to capture a stunning wide-angle of a flowerbed from below, and in the second we get creative with a flower, some water and a freezer.

title: Rhino off all fours by Geoffrey Lam
text:
Rhino off all fours by Geoffrey Lam
“This was taken at the Phinda game reserve, South Africa. While we were driving, a rhino came running out of the bushes right in front of our 4x4. I immediately took a few shots and caught one with it inches off the ground!”

title: Breath of Afrika by Damien Carduner
text:
Breath of Afrika by Damien Carduner
“This picture is a work between French choreographer and dancer Karlos Da Silva and I. I wanted to show Karlos’ African roots in a creative way, instead of simply taking a traditional portrait.”

title: Trail by Nikola Ostrun
text:
Trail by Nikola Ostrun
“This photo was taken near Varazdin in Croatia. It was a windy day and I was hoping to take long exposure shot of trail in wheat field. This was only shot with an interesting interplay between light and shadow.”

title: Silky Flies by Ya-Hsuan Tsai
text:
Silky Flies by Ya-Hsuan Tsai
“During the fireflies’ mating season, my friends and I found a quiet place in New Taipei City, Taiwan, and took this picture by chance, not knowing that it would come out with this surprising effect.”

title: Time Machine by Eric Fernandez
text:
Time Machine by Eric Fernandez
“This is La Cuave Del Indio (Indian’s Caves) in Arecibo, Puerto Rico. I decided to take a long exposure as the light was good and there were enough clouds to give dynamism to the scene.”

title: Misty Limbs by Michael Gibbs
text:
Misty Limbs by Michael Gibbs
“A view within Micheldever Wood, Hampshire. The smooth trunks of beech trees emerge from a carpet of bluebells on a misty morning. This was my fifth visit this year and I was looking to create a balanced composition through the trees.”

title: Tokyo Bay Cruise by Shingo Tamura
text:
Tokyo Bay Cruise by Shingo Tamura
“This scene shows Tokyo bay during twilight, taken in Ariake, Koto Ward. The long exposure reveals the lights of Rainbow Bridge and the light trails of passing boats.”

title: New issue of Photography Week out now!
text:
New issue of Photography Week out now!
This week we show you how to take summer snaps of family and friends and turn them into professional-looking portraits good enough to frame – and all with the minimum of effort and equipment. We also meet a fine-art photographer who literally creates her own beaches for portrait shoots with a difference; go behind the scenes with fashion and Photoshop Siren Miss Aniela; explain how to master exposure bracketing for spot-on exposures every time; and reveal the one Photoshop feature you can’t live without.

title: Tangara Gorgiplata by Raúl Vega
text:
Tangara Gorgiplata by Raúl Vega
“This photograph of a Silver-throated Tanager (Latin name Tangara icterocephala) was taken in San Isidro de Pérez Zeledón, near San José, Costa Rica. It is a common bird to find in this area.”

title: The Iris Nebula by Steve Furlong
text:
The Iris Nebula by Steve Furlong
“This is the beautiful Iris Nebula. I created this image from 53 long exposure photographs stacked together. Deep sky images are obtained by attaching a specialist cooled camera to a telescope, the telescope then effectively becoming the camera lens.”

title: Morning Has Broken by Bart Ceuppens
text:
Morning Has Broken by Bart Ceuppens
“For about three weeks each year the Japanese cherry trees are in blossom, and in Neerijse, Belgium, there’s a small avenue of them. I got up early to catch the sunrise coming through the mist, and was lucky to capture this scene.”

title: Duoyishu Dawn Fog by Paul Mullins
text:
Duoyishu Dawn Fog by Paul Mullins
“This was taken at Duoyishu, one of the villages nestled in amongst the tens of thousands of rice terraces in Yuanyang in Yunnan, China. It was taken shortly after dawn as the mist was rolling up from the valley floor.”

title: Girl from Adigrat by Sergio Carbajo
text:
Girl from Adigrat by Sergio Carbajo
“This was taken while trekking around the mountains in Adigrat, Tigray, in north Ethiopia. We met the young daughters of the village chief, and after some talking and playing, they agreed to allow us to take some photos.”

title: City Hall and the Shard by Matthew Dartford
text:
City Hall and the Shard by Matthew Dartford
“I’d planned this shot the day before my short visit to London. I was a little disappointed when the light wasn’t that interesting. Still, I hung around for about an hour waiting for the sun to drop, then captured this.”

title: We are One byRobert Mataković
text:
We are One byRobert Mataković
“This was taken in Zagreb, Croatia, and really it was a lucky shot. The little girl started to scratch the glass and the lioness started imitating the girl, so I quickly started shooting the scene.”

title: The latest issue of Photography Week is out now! Don’t forget you can get this issue – and the next five issues – completely FREE with our obligation-free trial at http://goo.gl/DWC7ND.
text:
The latest issue of Photography Week is out now! Don’t forget you can get this issue – and the next five issues – completely FREE with our obligation-free trial at http://goo.gl/DWC7ND.
Here’s what you’ve got to look forward to this week:

title: Gecko by Leon Dafonte Fernandez
text:
Gecko by Leon Dafonte Fernandez
“I took this where I live in Palm Cove, Queensland, Australia. I saw the gecko sitting on a the leaf of a tree on the beach, illuminated by the light of the sunset, and shot this handheld.”

title: Heybrook Bay by Jed Langdon
text:
Heybrook Bay by Jed Langdon
“This was taken in a small cove at Heybrook Bay, Plymouth. The sea was particularly choppy on this morning, so I used a long exposure to create a misty look around these rocks, with the Mewstone in the background.”

title: Lupine Field by Ryan Engstrom
text:
Lupine Field by Ryan Engstrom
This is a shot of Folsom lake in California. The lupine bloom here for a couple weeks a year in late April to mid May. During sunset the fading light can cast a soft warm glow that really lights up the flowers.“

title: Hepatica by Andreas Hagman
text:
Hepatica by Andreas Hagman
“It’s a tradition for me to capture the first flowers to pop up every spring. I like the Hepatica for their glowing colour when everything else is still dead and grey. This was taken in the countryside of southern Sweden.”

title: Crystal ball and coloured lights by Vivien Juhasz-Dora
text:
Crystal ball and coloured lights by Vivien Juhasz-Dora
“This is a photograph of a crystal ball lying on the railing of a bridge in Frankfurt, Germany. I focused on the skyline inside the ball with colourful lights creating a bokeh background.”

title: Wurmlingen Chapel rising from early morning mist by Michael Mehl
text:
Wurmlingen Chapel rising from early morning mist by Michael Mehl
“The photograph shows the chapel of Wurmlingen near the city of Tübingen, Germany, immersed in fog with the morning sun colouring it in an almost ethereal way. It required astonishingly little tweaking in post-processing.”

title: Storm Over Glencoe by Robert McBride
text:
Storm Over Glencoe by Robert McBride
“This image was made in Glencoe after heavy rain. The clouds started to break up and I saw this amazing light show. I shot handheld as I didn’t have enough time to set up a tripod before the moment was gone.”

title: New issue out now!
text:
New issue out now!
Our feature this week takes you step-by-step through the skills you need to shoot your first (or next) wedding, while award-winning wedding pro Lisa Aldersley shows us how it’s done – and dispenses some hard-earned wisdom on what it takes to turn a hobby into a living.

title: Buttermere by Tony Simpkins
text:
Buttermere by Tony Simpkins
“From where I stay in Buttermere Valley, Cumbria, it’s a short walk up the fell side on the northeast shore. I set off in unpromising conditions, before breakfast, to see if the light might cooperate, and fortunately it did.”

title: Anna’s Hummingbird by Jeff Bray
text:
Anna’s Hummingbird by Jeff Bray
“This shot of a male Anna’s Hummingbird was taken in Orange County, California at Tucker Wildlife Sanctuary. It has a unique habitat tucked into Modjeska Canyon where you can often see up to five species of hummingbird during migration season.”

title: Street Portrait by John Phillips
text:
Street Portrait by John Phillips
“I enjoy shooting streets at night, and with street portraits I look for light sources, then the background. That way when I see my subject I already know what the shot will look like before I look through the viewfinder.”

title: Little Blue Heron by Chuck Hantis
text:
Little Blue Heron by Chuck Hantis
“I heard there was a blue heron at a pond in Morristown, NJ. After an hour of searching I saw the heron fly over my head and land in the fir tree, and was lucky to get this shot.”

title: Orange tip butterfly by David Rounce
text:
Orange tip butterfly by David Rounce
“I got as close as I could to this butterfly, and with no image stabilisation on my lens I used a tripod and gimble head. Lucky for me he just sat still, allowing me to capture a couple of shots.”

title: Swallowed Whole by Raymond De Bui
text:
Swallowed Whole by Raymond De Bui
“This is a natural lava sinkhole off Oahu, Hawaii. I had to wait for the sun to be low enough to provide the side lighting to get the golden light on both the foreground and the surrounding lava rocks.”

title: Balloon over Bagan by Oscar Tarneberg
text:
Balloon over Bagan by Oscar Tarneberg
“Tourists enjoy the sunrise over Bagan from a hot-air balloon and the Shwesandaw Pagogda. This was taken from the top of one the more than 2,000 stupas scattered across the Bagan plains, one of the Myanmar’s most visited attractions.”

title: 2 Faces by Bruno Gracia Alcocer
text:
2 Faces by Bruno Gracia Alcocer
“I was walking through the streets on London early in the morning. I saw peoples’ reflection on the glass of the buildings, so waited for a couple of minutes to see if something interesting happened, and captured this shot.”

title: Praise the sun by Ewan Adamson
text:
Praise the sun by Ewan Adamson
“The ruins of Dunure Castle, South Ayrshire. I noticed the fast-changing light cast a warm glow on the castle. I wanted to include water and rocks in the foreground, so hopped from rock to rock until I was happy with the composition.”

title: Bullock’s Oriole by Linda Tanner
text:
Bullock’s Oriole by Linda Tanner
“I’m always excited about April when the Orioles migrate back to Atascadero, California, from as far away as South America. I put out feeders with nectar water and grape jelly, then sit still waiting for them to feed.”

title: Body and Soul by Christine Lutz
text:
Body and Soul by Christine Lutz
“I did a portfolio shoot for an upcoming model. We didn’t have a make-up artist or stylist – the focus lies on the natural beauty of Sofia who has a beautiful look, and a beautiful soul as well.”

title: Springtime by Soloross
text:
Springtime by Soloross
“I took this late one afternoon in Ticino park, near a river in northern Italy, close to my home. I backlight was perfect and I shot with the camera low to the ground.”

title: Lion Cub by Mike Thirkell
text:
Lion Cub by Mike Thirkell
“Lions Izu and Oshana of San Diego Safari Park became parents again. Oshana gave birth to a male and female, but for reasons unknown didn’t show interest in nursing them. They are being raised by zookeepers and are doing well.”

title: Botany Bay by Yue Xu
text:
Botany Bay by Yue Xu
“Botany Bay on Edisto Island, South Carolina is a unique place to photograph. Shooting from a low perspective, I used a wide angle lens to accentuate the long shadow created by the tree and the setting sun.”

title: NEW ISSUE OF PHOTOGRAPHY WEEK OUT NOW!
text:
NEW ISSUE OF PHOTOGRAPHY WEEK OUT NOW!
Our main feature this week takes a fresh look at summer landscapes, and shows how colour can be used to capture more original images.

title: Lightning Strikes by Leigh Burgess
text:
Lightning Strikes by Leigh Burgess
“I took this lightning photo at my local beach in Newcastle, Australia, when a late summer storm hit the area around 9pm. I was lucky to get there in time to get a couple of the last strikes before it moved out to sea.”

title: UFO Steel Landing by Henry Hiscox
text:
UFO Steel Landing by Henry Hiscox
“To take this shot, we put some steel wool into a whisk, which was then attached to a skipping rope so we could spin it. I had my camera on bulb mode, keeping the shutter open for 14 seconds.”

title: Thrum Mill by Neil Stalker
text:
Thrum Mill by Neil Stalker
“Thrum Mill, on the River Coquet, is near the village of Rothbury, Northumberland. After approximately 50 years standing derelict it was sold and restored into a private house. The owners have fitted an exact replica of the 10ft water wheel.”

title: Cynoglossum creticum mill by Salvo
text:
Cynoglossum creticum mill by Salvo
“I took this shot in a city park in Catania, Sicily. Cynoglossum creticum is a plant belonging to the Boraginaceae plant family, which is found in the Mediterranean Basin. I shot this using a tripod and macro lens.”

title: The Milky Way over farmland by Nobuyuki Kawashima
text:
The Milky Way over farmland by Nobuyuki Kawashima
“I captured the Milky Way and Venus over Lake Bumbunga in South Australia. The salt lake is a pink colour during the day time, and by night there are often clear, black skies here.”

title: Grooverider by Brian Walsh
text:
Grooverider by Brian Walsh
“I love low key club shots and this one was taken at the Que Club in Birmingham at a night called ‘Intervention’. I used a remote flash gun taped to the monitor speaker behind the subject to give the desired effect.”

title: Senja Sky Bridge by Daniel Kordan
text:
Senja Sky Bridge by Daniel Kordan
“This was taken on Senja Island, Norway, around midnight last summer. The weather changed quickly with dramatic rain clouds one side and the low sun opposite, creating this one-coloured rainbow, which is red due to the red light from the sun.”

title: Misty Sunrise by Jerry Lake
text:
Misty Sunrise by Jerry Lake
“Langley Park Lake is near Slough, Buckinghamshire. The sunrise looked good that morning around 7am; there was a frost on the ground, some ice at the edge of the lake, and a nice pink effect on the clouds, reflecting in the lake.”

title: Rio, Sugarloaf by Dmitry Pavlov
text:
Rio, Sugarloaf by Dmitry Pavlov
“This is a sunset view of Rio de Janeiro from Suagarloaf Mountain, one of the most popular spots in Rio. I saw the clouds rolling over the hills below me and decided to photograph the cable cars descending through the clouds.”

title: Booked by Robert Williams
text:
Booked by Robert Williams
“I was looking to shoot some outdoor photographs in the early morning fog when I found this location. This is a waterbird rookery where birds go to breed. The fog was starting to pull back as I captured this image.”

title: London in Motion by Torsten Muehlbacher
text:
London in Motion by Torsten Muehlbacher
“This is Tower Bridge, London. I took a few shots from different views, but this one was my favourite. I took a long exposure to capture traffic passing as streaks of light.”

title: Grytudden by David Olsson
text:
Grytudden by David Olsson
“This is Vänern, Sweden’s biggest lake in Grytudden. I shot this long exposure as the sun appeared on the horizon, painting the smoke from the chimneys orange, giving warm colours to the otherwise cold scene.”

title: Formosan Blue Shortwing in the moss by Fuyi Chen
text:
Formosan Blue Shortwing in the moss by Fuyi Chen
“This was taken in Alishan National Forest Recreation Area, Taiwan. I saw this Formosan Blue Shortwing in the grass looking for nesting material, and I couldn’t resist taking this shot.”

title: Burbujas de luz by Carla Gómez-Raggio
text:
Burbujas de luz by Carla Gómez-Raggio
“In this photo I’m trying to explain what inspiration means to me. The bubbles represent the moment ideas comes flying to my mind. I edited this shot in Photoshop adjusting layers, levels, curves and gradient maps, and then adding brushes.”

title: Sahara by Victoria Rivas
text:
Sahara by Victoria Rivas
“This was taken in Morocco in the Erg Chebbi Desert – a small part of the Sahara Desert. I liked the interplay between the light and shadows as the sun set.”

title: Total Lunar Eclipse by Asim Bharwani
text:
Total Lunar Eclipse by Asim Bharwani
A total Lunar Eclipse greeted the Western Hemisphere on the evening of April 14, 2014, the first of its kind in more than three years. This image is a series of stills taken over a two-hour period in Los Angeles, California. from the beginning of the journey to the point of total eclipse.“

title: Monkey in a red tree by Denis Richard
text:
Monkey in a red tree by Denis Richard
“This is a vervet monkey on the Caribbean island of St. Kitts. The red leaves of the tree are actually green, but they looked better when I altered the hue in post production.”

title: Radiant by Tristan O'Tierney
text:
Radiant by Tristan O'Tierney
“I was invited on a commercial shoot on top of the Bank of America building – the highest roof in San Francisco. I took this shot towards the end of sunset, as the light rays began passing through Nob Hill.”

title: Lago de Predil by Manuel Ferlitsch
text:
Lago de Predil by Manuel Ferlitsch
“Lago del Predil is a lake near Tarvisio, Italy in the beautiful Julian Alps. It was my first trip to this lake and the scenery just blew my mind. It’s a wonderful place to be.”

title: Magpie Glory by Mary Therit
text:
Magpie Glory by Mary Therit
“During a winter day in Colorado Springs I saw this black billed magpie searching for a tasty bit of something in the tall grasses. It snatched some food off the ground and landed on a nearby fence.”

title: Stortinden i Flakstad by Stein Liland
text:
Stortinden i Flakstad by Stein Liland
“This is the Star Mountains range taken on Flakstad Island, Lofoten in Norway. Winter light in Lofoten was amazing in January, when I shot this. I made some adjustments using the Curve tool in Photoshop when post-processing.”

title: The Moonlight Keepers by Alex Greenshpun
text:
The Moonlight Keepers by Alex Greenshpun
“I discovered these blossoms on a warm day. The sun illuminated them perfectly, while the shadow of a nearby tree created the dark background.”

title: Alyssa by Marcin Iskra
text:
Alyssa by Marcin Iskra
“My wife and I are wedding photographers in love with vintage style. We arranged a wedding inspired photo shoot during winter, and shot it in a Chicago warehouse. This image was taken by the window, using natural light and flash.”

title: Rowing in Green by Steven Krave
text:
Rowing in Green by Steven Krave
“This of the 2014 ‘Greening’ of the Chicago River for St. Patrick’s Day. I was crossing over Michigan avenue just after the greening event had finished up when this boat rowed by as part of a charity event.”

title: Silhouette by Steve Churcher
text:
Silhouette by Steve Churcher
“The was taken in Krabi, Thailand, and was one of a series of shots of my partner dancing in the sunset. We were trying to create a care-free, whimsical feel to the silhouette image.”

title: The Dawn will Come by Yuri Kriventsoff
text:
The Dawn will Come by Yuri Kriventsoff
“I decided to create a series of photos of New England lighthouses. Fort Pickering lighthouse on Winter Island in Salem, Massachusetts makes part of this series. It was built in 1871 and discontinued by the Coast Guard in 1969.”

title: Nebulous by Batu Balkanli
text:
Nebulous by Batu Balkanli
“On a sunny morning in Istanbul, I saw these wild daisies in a corner of a small street. They looked so beautiful, surrounded by concrete, steel and bricks. A few hours later they were all gone, probably picked up by someone.”

title: Pilsbury Castle by Kevin Palmer
text:
Pilsbury Castle by Kevin Palmer
“Pilsbury Castle is one of the finest examples of a motte-and-bailey castle ruin in the Peak District. I had arrived at this location one evening in April and decided to stay around for sunset – I’m so glad I did.”

title: The latest issue of Photography Week is out now!
text:
The latest issue of Photography Week is out now!
This week we take you step by step through the skills you need to shoot panoramics that will leave your friends’ jaws on the floor. And no, you don’t need any expensive kit or software!

title: Milky Way over Karang Cibobos, Sawarna by Abdul Azis
text:
Milky Way over Karang Cibobos, Sawarna by Abdul Azis
“After spending seven hours travelling by vehicle along a damaged road from Jakarta, we finally arrived at Cibobos Coral, Sawarna at 4am. As the sky was clear I took this shot by painting the rock.”

title: Pheasant by Justin Kibble
text:
Pheasant by Justin Kibble
“I took this during a drive around Suffolk. I saw this pheasant, who was distracted by a female pheasant out of shot, and stopped to take a shot. He spotted me and couldn’t decide whether to run or continue with the hen.”

title: Imperial County, California by Brock Whittaker
text:
Imperial County, California by Brock Whittaker
“My friends and I decided to stopped by the Imperial Sand Dunes that line the border between Arizona and California. The sunset came and provided me with the incredible light to capture the dunes as the shadows crept into the scene.”

title: Siren by Merika Almond
text:
Siren by Merika Almond
“My friend Natalie in the Yorkshire Dales. The image reminds me of the John William Waterhouse painting ‘Siren’ inspiring the mermaid look. I carried this through to post processing to create a painterly feel to the image.”

title: Gray Wagtail and Lotus by Fuyi Chen
text:
Gray Wagtail and Lotus by Fuyi Chen
“I found this wagtail foraging in the lotus pond at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei, Taiwan. As tourists frequently disturb the birds here, I had to wait a long time to capture this shot.”

title: Lilac-breasted Roller by Jeremy Smith
text:
Lilac-breasted Roller by Jeremy Smith
“I took this shot of two Lilac-breasted Rollers in Hwange National Park, Zimbabwe. I rested the camera on a travel pillow on the wing mirror of the vehicle we were traveling in, creating a stable base to lean on.”

title: Happy Friday by Lisa Holder
text:
Happy Friday by Lisa Holder
“I love to photograph flowers, especially with fresh dew or raindrops. This photo of a chrysanthemum was taken after a light rain when the clouds had just cleared. Nothing says spring like a pretty flower against a clear blue sky.”

title: Issue 82 of Photography Week out now!
text:
Issue 82 of Photography Week out now!
This week, we head down to the woods to shoot a stunning seasonal flower photo with a creative twist. We also bask in the wisdom of nature and wildlife legend Heather Angel, who’s known – among other things – for her impossibly cute pictures of panda cubs; discover how to shoot bison (in a good way); and get creative with a tripod-mounted camera, a hair dryer and a chocolate bunny – all will be revealed!

title: Dunstanburgh Castle Coastal View by Alan Dingwall
text:
Dunstanburgh Castle Coastal View by Alan Dingwall
“Dunstanburgh Castle lies on a headland on the coast of Northumberland, England. A long exposure shows the movement of the waves, revealing the beauty and wildness of the sea.”

title: Fog by Conrad Harley
text:
Fog by Conrad Harley
“This is a flooded field on the side of the road I commute down. Since the floods came in the UK I watched this location waiting for something interesting to happen, and one foggy morning I knew I had to stop.”

title: Durbar Square by Joshua Windsor
text:
Durbar Square by Joshua Windsor
“This was taken during an early morning amble around Durbar Square, the medieval centre of Kathmandu. I was captivated by the graceful temples and pigeons swooping around time-worn facades. A slow shutter speed was selected to accentuate the flurry.”

title: February Lightning III by Manuel Savariz Santos
text:
February Lightning III by Manuel Savariz Santos
“On a particularly stormy summer in Buenos Aires, the view from my balcony was a great place to capture lightning. One night, lightning was striking directly ahead, allowing me to shoot a series of shots.”

title: The Dawn will Come by Fearghal Breathnach
text:
The Dawn will Come by Fearghal Breathnach
“Taken at Whiterock beach, Killiney, Dublin. After a long spell of wet, miserable weather I realised that finally the sun might make an appearance on Sunday morning, so I headed out at 6am to see how the sunrise would play out.”

title: Eniye by David Pattinson
text:
Eniye by David Pattinson
“This is a photograph of my girlfriend Eniye, taken in Essen, Germany. I noticed the building in the background as we walked by, and took this shot. Contrasting a portrait with a regular geometric background is something I find interesting.”

title: North Rock Gutters by Catherine Marshall
text:
North Rock Gutters by Catherine Marshall
“Taken Broughton Island, Port Stephens, NSW, Australia. It’s a protected area for grey nurse sharks, where their numbers are increasing. The site was one called North Rock Gutters, where the sharks hang out in channels between the rock walls.”

title: Outdoor Reared by Sam Glover
text:
Outdoor Reared by Sam Glover
“This was taken on Baslow Edge near Curbar in Derbyshire. The Highland cattle that graze here are very friendly. This one had climbed on top of the rocks to drink from a puddle in the stone.”

title: Rocky Sunset by Colin Pallot
text:
Rocky Sunset by Colin Pallot
“I took this photograph at Corbiere on the island of Jersey. Looking for a unique shot, I spotted this group of rocks, and with the high tide and the sun setting, I thought it made a great photo opportunity.”

title: Sæbólskirkja by Kristinn R. Kristinnson
text:
Sæbólskirkja by Kristinn R. Kristinnson
“As a professional photo tour guide I get the opportunity to visit many beautiful locations here in Iceland, and this is one of them. Sæbólskirkja is located at Ingjaldssandur, a small valley on the south side of Önundarfjörður in Vestfirðir.”

title: Good Sense by Corinna van der Ven
text:
Good Sense by Corinna van der Ven
“This was taken at my home in the conservatory where I like to photograph flowers. Late in the afternoon when the light was at it’s best I captured this photo of the white Anemone.”

title: Into the Green World by Guillaume Launay
text:
Into the Green World by Guillaume Launay
”I saw this cricket and my impulse was to get closer. But in the viewfinder, it looked as if the cricket was keeping guard of the doors to his green world, so I stayed at a distance and framed the shot this way!“

title: Drisana by Thais Lima
text:
Drisana by Thais Lima
“This was taken in a cave in Serra Negra, Pernambuco, Brazil. It was a rainy day and had an air of mystery. I got my friend Drisanato look up as I stood behind some leaves to frame the shot.”

title: Bow Head Fiddle Blues by Philip Ure
text:
Bow Head Fiddle Blues by Philip Ure
“This is the second time I’ve been to Bow Fiddle Rock on the Moray Coast, Scotland. On my first visit the weather was bad with sleet and strong winds, but on this this visit the weather and light were much kinder.”

title: New issue of Photography Week out now!
text:
New issue of Photography Week out now!
Master slow shutter-speed landscapes, discover what it takes to shoot an exploding volcano, head to Hawaii to dive beneath the breaking waves, and much more!

title: Willet by Ryan Schain
text:
Willet by Ryan Schain
“I took this shot of a Willet in Chatham in Massachusettes. Willets are incredibly territorial shorebirds. I came across a pair of birds squabbling over territory, so I got on my stomach and waited for one to wander into frame.”

title: Harvest Mouse by Paul Tymon
text:
Harvest Mouse by Paul Tymon
“I saw some pictures of field mice on the internet, and was inspired to try some myself. They are amazing little creatures – very active, acrobatic and entertaining, as well as being very cute and a joy to photograph.”

title: San Giorgio Maggiore by Ernesto Vicinanza
text:
San Giorgio Maggiore by Ernesto Vicinanza
“This was taken in Venice, Italy. In the background you can see the basilica on the island of San Giorgio Maggiore, which was designed by Andrea Palladio.”

title: Senza Titolo by Angelo Metauri
text:
Senza Titolo by Angelo Metauri
“I coloured the water with food colouring, using a high-speed flash, which freezes the splash into different shapes.”

title: Road to Glencoe by Mat Roberts
text:
Road to Glencoe by Mat Roberts
“Glencoe, Scotland, has some of the most dramatic scenery in the world, and some of the most changeable weather. It’s a great place for hiking, but sometimes the best images are right there in front of you on the road ahead.”

title: Spring by Tomasz Skoczen
text:
Spring by Tomasz Skoczen
“I carefully arranged this scene in my garden, placing moss in the background and sprinkling the ladybird with water drops. It was a sunny day, so there was no need to use flash. I shot this handheld.”

title: Bree by Sara Mellotti
text:
Bree by Sara Mellotti
“This image was taken in the Nevada Desert. I was able to take advantage of the beautiful sunlight to shoot backlit. This photo shoot was for personal work.”

title: Trees In The Mist by Juan Valdés
text:
Trees In The Mist by Juan Valdés
“I took this photo on a cold morning on Pebble Beach, California. This tree-covered hill shrouded in mist caught my eye as it created an incredible atmosphere, and Lightroom did the rest.”

title: Wild in Castelluccio by Matteo Mazzatti
text:
Wild in Castelluccio by Matteo Mazzatti
“One morning, I decided to photograph the sunrise on the plain of Castelluccio di Norcia, Italy. After a night of time lapse, dawn arrived, and with it a herd of horses approached to drink and graze. It was an unforgettable moment.”

title: Noir City by Emiliano Iko
text:
Noir City by Emiliano Iko
“This is a tribute to film noir. It was taken handheld with a compact camera, using the help of a friend who posed for me in an old city palace late at night, while the city slept.”

title: Herd of Male Red Lechwe by Susan Roehl
text:
Herd of Male Red Lechwe by Susan Roehl
“This image of a herd of male lechwe was taken in the Moremi Game Reserve in Botswana. I was on a photographic tour to capture images of wildlife, and we stopped to photograph these antelope.”

title: I See The Light… by Chris Sanders
text:
I See The Light… by Chris Sanders
“This was a photo I took while walking our dogs in the local park. The crocuses were out, the late afternoon light was good, and this bee came along at just the right moment to complete the shot.”

title: Watching the Sunrise by Mohamed Shareef
text:
Watching the Sunrise by Mohamed Shareef
“Crows scavenge for food along the beaches of inhabited islands of Maldives, making a perfect silhouette against the rising sun. This crow was waiting for its breakfast as the sun rose across the beautiful Eydhafushi island of Baa Atoll in Maldives.”

title: Myanmar – Misty dawn over Bagan by Anh Nguyen
text:
Myanmar – Misty dawn over Bagan by Anh Nguyen
”This was taken in Bagan, Myanmar, while climbing to the top of Shwesandaw Pagoda. Although every guidebook suggests viewing the sunset over the ancient site from here, the dawn is much much more majestic, with or without the air balloons.”

title: Olas by Juan Sanchez-Donostia
text:
Olas by Juan Sanchez-Donostia
“I took this shot near my house at Deba, on the coast of Gipuzkoa in Basque country, Spain during a storm at sea one evening.”

title: On the Jetty by Claire Gentile
text:
On the Jetty by Claire Gentile
“I asked some friends to join me at the beach to spin steel wool on the jetty as the moon was rising. I wanted to include the texture and drama of the rocks, as well as the glow from the sparks.”

title: The answer is blowing in the wind by Carlo Scherer
text:
The answer is blowing in the wind by Carlo Scherer
“This was taken on the ‘Dune de Pilat’, the largest wandering dune in Europe, located on the Atlantic coast of France, near Bordeaux. It was a bit windy and my dog highly appreciated these weather conditions.”

title: Silence by Huang Qing
text:
Silence by Huang Qing
“I took this picture one night in Yichang, China. I love the city at night, especially when you venture into the alleys. This alleyway was filled by an unbroken silence, creating a great mood for photographing.”

title: Ha̍p-hoan-soa by James Wang
text:
Ha̍p-hoan-soa by James Wang
“This was taken in Hehuanshan, Ha̍p-hoan-soa, a high mountain in central Taiwan. My friend and I carried our camera equipment up 1.7 kilometers of the mountain, where temperatures dropped to around -3°C.”

title: Offspring by Daniel Frauchiger
text:
Offspring by Daniel Frauchiger
“A young beech tree on a early fall morning taken in Thalheim, Aargau, Switzerland. I got up early to photograph the sun breaking through the fog in the forest. The sun didn’t drive away the fog entirely, creating this nice atmosphere.”

title: Abbie by Pauly Pholwises
text:
Abbie by Pauly Pholwises
“For this shot, I was worried that the sun would be too high, resulting in harsh shadows, but the light was perfect and created a nice backlight. Having her hold the flowers brings more interest to the photo.”

title: Lexie by Nathan Eaton
text:
Lexie by Nathan Eaton
“This is a portrait of Lexie, our seven year old Weimaraner, taken in my makeshift home studio using black coat as backdrop. It was post-processed in Lightroom 5 for to make it black and white.”

title: San Diego, Ocean Beach by William Dunigan
text:
San Diego, Ocean Beach by William Dunigan
“I’ve always loved walking San Diego’s coast at sunrise. I caught this scene along the jagged heights of Sunset Cliffs Park. Brooding clouds parted, the sun peaked through, and a dazzling light show ensued.”

title: Reach Out by Dane Gardner
text:
Reach Out by Dane Gardner
“I always look forward to this time of year when crocuses and snowdrops emerge. As the sun shines on them the flowers open up allowing me to photograph them in all their glory.”

title: Ili, Nalati Grassland by Jaymar Alvaran
text:
Ili, Nalati Grassland by Jaymar Alvaran
“I took this through the window of a moving bus across the vast Nalati grassland, near the town of Ili in Xinjiang, China. We were racing to reach the nearest peak for sunset, to capture the best view.”

title: Evening Geranium by Jacob Edmiston
text:
Evening Geranium by Jacob Edmiston
“I was walking at local park when I came upon this beautiful geranium patch. Since there were many flowers in the patch, I lowered my depth of field to produce the blurred, colourful background.”

title: Waves of the East I by Andrew Gray
text:
Waves of the East I by Andrew Gray
“I love how the character of the sea changes each day. I’ve been capturing images of the sea off the Northumberland coast for years, and recently started using panning techniques and a longer exposure time to capture my shots.”

title: The Weightlessness of an Artist’s Soul by Omálix
text:
The Weightlessness of an Artist’s Soul by Omálix
“This self-portrait was taken near a small lake on the side of a road in Orlando, Florida. It’s about the way artists feel and perceive the world, and how we can be emotionally uplifted in our own world of ideas.”

title: Receding Coastline by David Inscho
text:
Receding Coastline by David Inscho
“The receding tide allowed a safe tripod shot on the beach when I reached the photo site. A fading day made the softness of longer exposures easy. Washington beaches feature solitude, sea stacks, and massive logs from Olympic old-growth.”

title: The sky is filled with stars, invisible by day… by Sandeep Thomas
text:
The sky is filled with stars, invisible by day… by Sandeep Thomas
“This shot was taken at the Pfeiffer State Beach at Big Sur, California, known for a natural bridge formation on the beach. During January, the sun sets directly through the arch.”

title: Dedicata a Chiara by Minetti Emanuele
text:
Dedicata a Chiara by Minetti Emanuele
“This is an image I prepared for an international non-profit project. The location is the Museo Nazionale della Scienza e della Tecnologia Leonardo da Vinci, department of rail transport in Milan, Italy.”

title: Lindesnes Panorama by Tore Heggelund
text:
Lindesnes Panorama by Tore Heggelund
“This was taken at the southernmost point of Norway, the Lindesnes lighthouse. There was a strong wind and heavy snow showers that day. The photo is a panorama composed of 10 images, stitched with PtGui and processed with Lightroom.”

title: Darkness by Mark Edwards
text:
Darkness by Mark Edwards
“This was taken in a local woodland near where I live in Reading. Myself and a friend lit up the woods with some bright lighting. We then used plumbers smoke pellets to create a mist and experimented with long exposures.”

title: Winter Terrace by Steven Hazlett
text:
Winter Terrace by Steven Hazlett
“This was taken on a cold afternoon in New York’s Central Park. I noticed this man in his fur coat, so I spoke with him briefly about taking a picture. He agreed and we made this photograph.”

title: Amaryllis flowers, focus stacked by Anthony Worsdell
text:
Amaryllis flowers, focus stacked by Anthony Worsdell
“My amaryllis is now almost in full bloom, with four out of the five buds having blossomed spectacularly. This image was focus stacked from 12 photos using Helicon Remote, Helicon Focus and Lightroom 5.”

title: Giant Sequoias by Matt Lief Anderson
text:
Giant Sequoias by Matt Lief Anderson
“This is Coopman enjoying the first snow of the year during a recent road trip to Sequoia National Park in California. I edited this shot with VSCO in Lightroom.”

title: Towers by Eugene Wahrlich
text:
Towers by Eugene Wahrlich
“Light conditions change rapidly at the Torres del Paine National Park, Chile. I had been shooting a wandering guanoco and was fortunate that the clouds cleared for a few seconds, revealing the towers.”

title: Makeup? by Simone Malatesta
text:
Makeup? by Simone Malatesta
“The story of my life is that I apply makeup because I don’t want life to recognise me. I took this self portrait (which is the second of five images) at my house for a small project.”

title: Behind Bars by Pedro Dias Molins
text:
Behind Bars by Pedro Dias Molins
“This was taken in the town of Porto, Portugal, on the top of the Dom Luis Bridge.”

title: Murphy’s Haystacks by Jacqui Barker
text:
Murphy’s Haystacks by Jacqui Barker
“This was taken at Murphy’s Haystacks, located between Port Kenny and Streaky Bay in Australia. I’d been taking photos of the sunset when I turned around and noticed the beautiful backlight with the moon rising.”

title: Gratitude by Lars Ahlgreen
text:
Gratitude by Lars Ahlgreen
“This photo was taken during my visit to Cambodia at a small local market outside of Siem Reap. My guide took me to meet this lady, who had lost her entire family during the Khmer Rouge regime.”

title: First Light by Steve Mendenhall
text:
First Light by Steve Mendenhall
“This image of Lone Pine Peak at sunrise was taken from the Alabama Hills, west of Lone Pine in California. It was taken while on a camping trip and was about a 10 minute walk from our camp.”

title: Sunshine in Yao Village by Chen Min
text:
Sunshine in Yao Village by Chen Min
“This photo was taken in a small Yao village in Guangdong Province, China. Yao people are one of the ethnic minorities in China. I saw this girl walking through these ginkgo trees, and took this shot.”

title: Five Minutes From Reality by Michael Marsh
text:
Five Minutes From Reality by Michael Marsh
“I shot this image on the day of our arrival from England to the underbelly of The Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York. This man was a member of staff taking his five minute break from reality.”

title: Shadow of the Ibex by Gilles Baechler
text:
Shadow of the Ibex by Gilles Baechler
“A friend and I decided to climb the Vanil Noir in Fribourg, Switzerland. Near the summit, we were surrounded by alpine ibex! I took this from the north face while the sun was behind the mountain.”

title: Equilibrium by Noel Clegg
text:
Equilibrium by Noel Clegg
“This image was taken in Knokke, Belgium. The canals around Knokke are all lined with these trees, and I was delighted to find this location to create this shot.”

title: Sandnes Sunrise by Magnus Larsson
text:
Sandnes Sunrise by Magnus Larsson
“This was taken in Lofote, Norway. I’d planned to photograph the sunrise from a different location, but saw I was in the wrong location to capture it. So I quickly drove to a location that enabled me to capture this spectacular scene.”

title: Ink by Emma Brabrook
text:
Ink by Emma Brabrook
“Some double exposures and beautiful ink photos inspired me, so I decided to mix the two ideas. I took a self-portrait and combined it with photos of ink. Capturing the ink was simple: a vase of water in front of my shoot-through umbrella!”

title: Dampflok Im Schnee by Gerald Grote
text:
Dampflok Im Schnee by Gerald Grote
“This was taken on top of the Brocken, the highest of the few mountains in northern Germany. I hiked up early in the morning to get some sunrise shots. Luckily the fog disappeared just in time as this train passed.”

title: Complices by Cyril Blanchard
text:
Complices by Cyril Blanchard
“Zina caught my attention among a large group of children playing on the beach on a tiny island off Madagascar, Nosy Mitsio. Light conditions were very bright, so I took advantage of the palm tree shadows to capture this portrait.”

title: Pretend I’m a Waxwing by Alison Brown
text:
Pretend I’m a Waxwing by Alison Brown
“I found this female blackbird feeding on rowan berries. I liked the background of golden leaves and used enough depth of field to keep the bird and a few berries in sharp focus, yet blur the background.”

title: Cirque du Soleil by Shed Mojahid
text:
Cirque du Soleil by Shed Mojahid
“For this image, I wanted to give a floating effect without using Photoshop. I think a lot about position and movement when photographing, and for the location, when we find a good place, I simply stop the car shoot!”

title: Breakfast of Champions by Melissa Ross
text:
Breakfast of Champions by Melissa Ross
“This was taken in my kitchen using natural light from the surrounding windows. I wanted to convey how a photograph could say, ‘Good morning!’ What better way to greet the day than two pieces of warm toast leaping happily into your hands?”

title: Fisherman by Thomas Kamensky
text:
Fisherman by Thomas Kamensky
“I took the picture in Barr Nova in Brazil. While walking on the beach one morning, I saw this old fisherman on his boat silhouetted by the light from the sunrise. This is one of ten shots from that morning.”

title: Goldie in the Sun by Lolly Twigg
text:
Goldie in the Sun by Lolly Twigg
“I captured this image of a male goldfinch in my garden in Fife. With the light of the sun I was able to have a low ISO and a fast shutter speed, enabling me to capture the motion of the wings.”

title: Close to Heavens by Samuel Berthelot
text:
Close to Heavens by Samuel Berthelot
“I took this while cycling through Guangxi in China. This is the beautiful and breathtaking Karst rock formation near Yangshuo. The weather conditions weren’t good, so to make the photo more exciting, I gave the sky an orange tint using Lightroom.”

title: New issue of Photography Week out now for iPad & iPhone!
text:
New issue of Photography Week out now for iPad & iPhone!
This issue we’ve got a fantastic feature on capturing stunning light-trail images – from traffic and star trails to light-painting and more, we’ve got it covered. We also meet up with a legendary travel photographer who’s sold more than four million photo books, and reveal the secret of his success; go behind the scenes of a famous photoshoot with sixties sex symbol Brigitte Bardot; and show you how to make the most of your camera’s movie mode. Plus, we tell you what we think of the waterproof Nikon 1 AW1 compact system camera. Enjoy!

title: Bangkok Traffic by Mark Burban
text:
Bangkok Traffic by Mark Burban
“This image is comprised of nine separate long exposures, and stacked using a post processing method using HDR techniques, allowing me to extend exposure time to several minutes, revealing a hidden world of movement.”

title: Water Bird by Uma Kotturu
text:
Water Bird by Uma Kotturu
“It was fascinating to observe this beautiful Painted Stork at Delhi Zoological Park. It would repeatedly fill water in its beak from the lake. It would then return to its nest to gives the water to its chicks.”

title: 50s Aren’t Dead by Sandra Slead
text:
50s Aren’t Dead by Sandra Slead
“This photo was taken in the Superstition Mountain OHV Open Area during a camping trip. My friend was riding his Honda CRF 50 Pit Bike when I took this shot.”

title: Twins by Marcin Kubiak
text:
Twins by Marcin Kubiak
“This shot, taken in Zakopane, Poland, is a part of a bigger project in which I try to create unreal, surrealistic constructions from existing buildings. All shots are taken on analog cameras with double or multi exposure of one frame of film.”

title: Millions of snowflakes by Anne Geier
text:
Millions of snowflakes by Anne Geier
“This is a photograph of my dog Cindy. She came from an animal shelter and has been in our family for six years she and enjoys every minute of her life. She especially loves the snow.”

title: Good Bye Eyes 03 Alessandro Vannucci
text:
Good Bye Eyes 03 Alessandro Vannucci 
“While I was waiting for my train at Varanasi railway station in India, I had time to stroll around between the trains with my camera approaching the people at the window. This photo is from a series of 10 shots.”

title: Montmorency Falls Ice Cone by Yvette Depaepe
text:
Montmorency Falls Ice Cone by Yvette Depaepe
“The Montmorency Falls are located near Quebec City. During winter, spray from the falls freezes into a large ice cone. You can walk on it at your own risk. The most adventurous climb to the top and abseil back down.”

title: Alexandra by Pini Hamou
text:
Alexandra by Pini Hamou
“This was captured in an abandoned hotel near Jerusalem. The image is comprised of two images – the first of the background only, and then one of the model is lying on a chair. I later removed the chair in Photoshop.”

title: These Magic Moments by Dora Artemiadi
text:
These Magic Moments by Dora Artemiadi
“I woke up before sunrise to photograph a famous old bridge. When I arrived, I was thrilled by the colours of the surrounding landscape. The colours and light lasted only for a few minutes.”

title: Juvenile Wild Rabbit by Wouter Marck
text:
Juvenile Wild Rabbit by Wouter Marck
“This image was taken in the dunes near Scheveningen in Holland. Wild rabbits are incredibly alert but eventually, after spending about seven or eight summer evenings with them, I gained their trust, allowing me to get closer.”

title: Himalayan Dream by Terry Roberts
text:
Himalayan Dream by Terry Roberts
“I took this early in the morning near Annapurna Base Camp, Nepal, 4100m above sea level. It was taken on the morning of a rescue of two French climbers who had completed an ascent, but who had become victims of the bad weather.”

title: Beckon by David Talley
text:
Beckon by David Talley
“I created this image on a sea cliff at Laguna Beach, California on a stormy day. The final image combines shots taken of the model, the surrounding area, clouds, and separate pieces of blue dress billowing in the wind.”

title: San Juan de Gaztelugatxe by Antonio Prado
text:
San Juan de Gaztelugatxe by Antonio Prado
“This is Gaztelugatxe islet on the Biscay Coast. This image is comprised of two shots edited in Camera Raw and combined in Photoshop. I used Color Efex Suit to give more strength to the image and warmth to the sky.”

title: The Polar Fox by Kim Abel
text:
The Polar Fox by Kim Abel
“This polar fox was photographed at Svalbard. Some polar foxes can be quite curious, and so was this one. Shot in the middle of the night, the light of the midnight sun behind clouds made taking this photograph possible.”

title: Zjoske looking outside by Kris Van de Vjer
text:
Zjoske looking outside by Kris Van de Vjer
“In this shot I mix fiction with reality. I’m trying to find something unexplainable, and highlight the undefined in real-life situations, and thus escape the banality of everyday life in the process.”

title: Minor Trees by Callum Baker
text:
Minor Trees by Callum Baker
“I began with an old shot that was perfect for blending exposures, and combined it with a tree line silhouette in Photoshop by adjusting the blending mode. I applied a few tweaks and textures and ended up with this image.”

title: Misty Morning by Janine Jones
text:
Misty Morning by Janine Jones
“I took this on a visit to my aunt’s at Crowe Lake, Ontario. I wanted to photograph the sunrise, but was greeted by mist instead! The little island was once owned by my uncle, who donated it to the Marmora Historical Society.”

title: Fetching Water by Daniel Frauchiger
text:
Fetching Water by Daniel Frauchiger
“This young girl was fetching water from the river to bring to her house in a remote village in Phongsali Province, Laos. Our group was only the fifth group of foreigners to visit this village, which had no road access.”

title: By Dmitry Trishin
text:
By Dmitry Trishin
“The purpose of this picture is to bring attention to the red of her lips and hair. I used natural light, and simple edits when post processing. I did basic retouching using Photoshop and Lightroom, adjusting colour temperature and contrast.”

title: Storm by Olivier Gaultier
text:
Storm by Olivier Gaultier
“This panorama of seven photos was taken in Brittany, France during the passing of a storm. Instead of waiting until dark, I made modifications in Photoshop and included another shot I took with the lighthouse lit. My goal was to create drama.”

title: ISSUE 69 OUT NOW FOR iPAD AND iPHONE!
text:
ISSUE 69 OUT NOW FOR iPAD AND iPHONE!
Following on from our two-part series on essential shooting and editing skills, this issue’s feature talks you through what to do if it all goes wrong – and when and how to go ‘wrong’ deliberately for more creative images.

title: Looking Down by Mattias Hammar
text:
Looking Down by Mattias Hammar
“The Roxy Pro France surf competition had a late night heat at Le Penon, France. At the end of her heat, Lakey Peterson (pictured here) realised she wouldn’t win it, and threw this backflip just for show.”

title: Pierce the Sun by Mohamad Adura
text:
Pierce the Sun by Mohamad Adura
“This was taken during my morning ride with my friend in Kampung Sungai Melayu, Johor, Malaysia. This is an old palm oil estate and this road connects a new highway to a remote fishing village.”

title: Ama Dablam Star Trails by Mason Cummings
text:
Ama Dablam Star Trails by Mason Cummings
“This is Ama Dablam under moonlight, seen from the village of Dingboche in the Everest region of the Himalayas. The final image consists of 61 30-second exposures stacked using the Waguila Star Trail Stacker script for Photoshop.”

title: Snow Leopard by Sue Demetriou
text:
Snow Leopard by Sue Demetriou
“When editing this image, I blackened the background and removed all colour in Photoshop, and used oOne Software to create the mist in the foreground. The snow was achieved by using Auto FX Software, Mystical Suite.”

title: Misty Patterns by Amir Eltahan
text:
Misty Patterns by Amir Eltahan
“Being one of the only foreigners to have visited PuZheHei, Yunnan Province in China at the time this was taken, I found it to be an untouched heaven. Beautiful fields, friendly people and amazing nature.”

title: Paris in the Fog by Patrik Mauric
text:
Paris in the Fog by Patrik Mauric
“At first I was disappointed by the fog, as I wasn’t able to see the Eiffel Tower in all its flory, but after I saw how this picture turned out, I was glad of the fog!”

title: Ladakh, India by Yury Pustovoy
text:
Ladakh, India by Yury Pustovoy
“This was taken in Ladakh, India, in a village near the border of Pakistan. It’s a hard living in the mountain villages of this area – young children have to work alongside adults.”

title: The Wind And The Moon by José Manuel Román Gómez
text:
The Wind And The Moon by José Manuel Román Gómez
“Taken in Tarifa, Spain, where over time strong winds have shaped the trees into curious forms. I used a long exposure and artificial light project onto the tree.”

title: In a one-off Gallery Special, the latest issue of Photography Week features our selection of the most breathtaking images of 2013, from award-winning news and sport photography, to landscapes, portraits, wildlife and more.
text:
In a one-off Gallery Special, the latest issue of Photography Week features our selection of the most breathtaking images of 2013, from award-winning news and sport photography, to landscapes, portraits, wildlife and more.
You can get this special edition, plus our next four regular issues, completely FREE if you sign up for our risk-free trial. And if you then decide to subscribe, each issue works out at less than 60c/40p a pop – bargain!.

title: Eastbourne Pier by Lee Roberts
text:
Eastbourne Pier by Lee Roberts
“This is Eastbourne pier in Sussex, England. The sunrise was beautiful on this stormy day. I took the shot from the water’s edge using a wide angled lens. This was the final shot as it resulted in my getting soaked!”

title: Maramania by Mara de la Hoz
text:
Maramania by Mara de la Hoz
“I photographed this wildebeest migration in the Masai Mara last August. I wanted to capture the river crossing: a photo that could describe the tense moment, the motion, the madness and the animals’ anxiety in trying to reach the other side.”

title: Hossa by Max Fransen
text:
Hossa by Max Fransen
“This was taken in my hometown of Breda, the Netherlands, and shows a local skateboarder who’s always looking for new places to skate. Even during bad weather, he’s often our skating.”

title: Storm Coming by Vincent Waldron
text:
Storm Coming by Vincent Waldron
“It was the end of November and there were storms moving across the midwest US. Our weather radio indicated tornado warnings in our area, and I noticed the odd cloud formation moving toward our home, so I took this shot.”

title: By Mikko Palosaari
text:
By Mikko Palosaari
“I’d wanted to photograph wide-angle shots by this lake, but decided to focus on details around the shore. I used my 135mm f/1.8 with the aperture wide open to get this dreamy look as the sun set.”

title: Avenir by Johnny Yim
text:
Avenir by Johnny Yim
“I’m very interested in telling stories in puddles. In this shot, I tried to show a surreal world that captures a kind of melancholy.”

title: Hamnøy by Antonio Prado
text:
Hamnøy by Antonio Prado
“I had this photograph in mind before travelling to Norway, so I planned how to capture this scene well in advance. It was taken at the fishing village of Hamnøy, at Moskenesøy Island in Lofoten.”

title: Mylene by Sara Melotti
text:
Mylene by Sara Melotti
“I shot this image last year, two months after I started photographing. It was for a personal project in which I wanted to experiment using snow as a theme.”

title: A Mouthful by Kim Abel
text:
A Mouthful by Kim Abel
“In the north of Norway we’ve had lots of whales following the herring along the coast during winter. I was lucky to see 10 humpbacks and 30 killer whales feeding on a school of herring, and I took this shot.”

title: Last Winter Walk by Elena Shumilova
text:
Last Winter Walk by Elena Shumilova
“This was our last walk of winter last year. It was a beautiful day with clear snow and a perfect winter sun. We all were in a good mood, which I hope you can feel from the photo.”

title: Still Snowing by Mark Tizard
text:
Still Snowing by Mark Tizard
“I took this image from inside my garage. It was an overcast day and there were dark trees behind, which were great for emphasising the snow. I used spot metering to get the correct exposure on the robin.”

title: Closer by Maja Topčagić
text:
Closer by Maja Topčagić
“We went to the mountain near Sarajevo, Bosnia, to capture winter shots as there was no snow in the city. The model is Nejla Hadzic. I really like this portrait as I think it captures her unique beauty.”

title: Neon by Alexey Kljatov
text:
Neon by Alexey Kljatov
“I photograph snowflakes on a glass plate, lit by an LED flashlight, although sometimes I use natural light. I use dark woollen fabrics as a background. For more on my technique visit my blog.”

title: First Snow by Zaneta Frenn
text:
First Snow by Zaneta Frenn
“It was a snowy Sunday afternoon, as we arrived at an old restaurant. These two kids were sitting in the window to watch the snow fall. It was a simple and magical moment that I was lucky enough to capture.”

title: Diamonds Drifting by Carlos Resende
text:
Diamonds Drifting by Carlos Resende
“This is a shot of Jökulsárlón black sand beach in Iceland – an undoubtedly wonderful location to photograph at sunrise or sunset when the icebergs on the black sand are lit up.”

title: Klifatindur by Dennis Polkläser
text:
Klifatindur by Dennis Polkläser
“The picture was taken around 12 o’ clock, approximately two hours after sunrise, and shows the Klifatindur mountains in eastern Iceland. Visible are the peaks Kambhorn (left), Vetrahorn (middle), and Brunnhorn (right).”

title: Pounce by Henrik Nilsson
text:
Pounce by Henrik Nilsson
“This coyote is pouncing on a rodent. Shortly before I captured this, I was photographing landscapes in Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming. When I saw this coyote, I immediately took the opportunity to photograph it as it pounced.”

title: The Snowy Cloak of Aldeyjarfoss by Erez Marom
text:
The Snowy Cloak of Aldeyjarfoss by Erez Marom
“Arguably the most beautiful and impressive waterfall I’ve ever seen, Aldeyjarfoss is even more impressive in its frozen winter clothing, and this image doesn’t begin to do it justice. In winter, it is reachable only by super jeeps, but getting there was definitely worth the hardship.”

title: Five Minutes From Reality by Lars-Espen Langhaug
text:
Five Minutes From Reality by Lars-Espen Langhaug
“This image is composed of six exposures and was taken just outside Tromsø, on the island of Kvaløya in Norway. As the aurora was so large, I needed to capture it as a panorama.”

title: Red Grouse by Sam Linton
text:
Red Grouse by Sam Linton
“I photographed this red grouse taken in the Scottish Highlands. This male grouse stood tall on a wall and allowed me to get very close using my car as a hide. I managed to capture him doing his terrific call.”

title: Last Winter Walk by Elena Shumilova
text:
Last Winter Walk by Elena Shumilova
“I really like to spend my time waiting for moments like this. It was a foggy day as I was walking with my son and dog, and I knew that I wanted to capture this scene.”

title: The latest issue of Photography Week is out now for iPAD and iPHONE! Don’t forget, you can get your first five issues COMPLETELY FREE with our no-obligation, risk-free trial. If you subscribe, issues are delivered direct to your iPad or iPhone (or both!), every Thursday, for less than 60c/40p an issue. That’s cheaper than a can of Coke! To find out more, simply search for Photography Week in the App Store, or follow the link below…http://goo.gl/BBkmxR
text:
The latest issue of Photography Week is out now for iPAD and iPHONE! Don’t forget, you can get your first five issues COMPLETELY FREE with our no-obligation, risk-free trial. If you subscribe, issues are delivered direct to your iPad or iPhone (or both!), every Thursday, for less than 60c/40p an issue. That’s cheaper than a can of Coke! To find out more, simply search for Photography Week in the App Store, or follow the link below…http://goo.gl/BBkmxR
Here’s what you’ve got to look forward to this week:

title: Superb Fairy-Wren by Andrew Haysom
text:
